    <tei-p data-origname="p">Sometimes, a whim, a resurgence of barbarity seizes a master, and no matter what potential prejudice such atrocious satisfaction might possibly bring him, he has a man, his peer, his equal, sacrificed. These acts of cold cruelty are so far from our mores that we, born in the colonies, cannot comprehend them. Often, an honorable skepticism guards us against the accounts of our correspondents. Would to God that they were all false! We would be the first to proclaim them so, and our hearts would not be burdened by painful impressions.</tei-p>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">Here are two new facts to record in the long list of crimes that makes up colonial history. There we not only see a colonist committing a heinous murder, but another ordering it to be carried out by his slaves, thus demoralizing these unfortunate individuals who, at the risk of their lives, could not refuse the orders they received.</tei-p>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">In <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, un landowner in the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">commune of La Rivière Pilote</tei-placeName>, a landowner in the commune of La Rivière Pilote, apparently convinced that he had reason to complain about his slave Gabriel, summoned six slaves from his workshop on April 16 and ordered them to bring him Gabriel's head. The slaves promised obedience.</tei-p>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">Gabriel, unofficially informed of his master's intentions, went to see him and offered 3,535 francs for his redemption. The master replied that he would consider it. Although this reply was nothing short of satisfactory, the unfortunate Gabriel set about realizing his funds, and went to the market town of Le Marin to sell his flour. As he was leaving, six negroes ambushed him, drove him to the sugar mill, tied him to a calabash tree and killed him. One of the executioners then went to the owner, who, having heard the story of the murder, simply replied coldly: <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">That is well</tei-emph></tei-q>.</tei-p><tei-pb n="28" facs="v1n1p28" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">However, the planter, having gone to the place where Gabriel's mutilated corpse lay, couldn't stand the dreadful sight for long: he withdrew, and with the help of his sugar maker, spread the rumor that Gabriel had been killed by a mule. He sent word to the Commune's Commissar, but public rumor had beaten him to it, and the Commissar came with the Justice of the Peace and two doctors to perform an autopsy on the corpse. The type of death was then recognized, and among other wounds, a gunshot wound to the lower jaw. A report was drawn up and deposited at <tei-placeName ref="#FoR" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Fort-Royal</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">In the same colony, in the commune of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Macouba</tei-placeName>, a wealthy owner was accused by the public of killing his slaves. The public prosecutor went to the property and found an unfortunate woman lying lifeless. The master had cruelly castigated her, and she had expired under the lashes. To ascertain whether the corpse was still alive, the cruel master went so far as to pierce his victim's belly with a hot iron. The courts are investigating the case, but the colonist accused of the crime is on the run. The new governor, <tei-persName ref="#EH" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Halgan</tei-persName>, has hastened to send details of this act of colonial monstrosity to the Ministry of the Navy.</tei-p>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">It is to be hoped that, in the interests of justice and humanity, such crimes will not go unpunished. The honor of the government and the salvation of the colony are at stake; for where the reign of justice ceases, the right of might and violence is born.  </tei-p></tei-div>
    <tei-div xml:id="france" id="france" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head data-origname="head">FRANCE.</tei-head>
    <tei-head data-origname="head">PARIS.</tei-head>
    <tei-head data-origname="head">CONVOCATION OF THE CHAMBERS.</tei-head>
    
    <tei-p data-origname="p">The following ordinance is published in the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#MU" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Moniteur</tei-title></tei-bibl> of <tei-date data-origname="date">July 1</tei-date>, dated <tei-date data-origname="date">June 30</tei-date> and countersigned by <tei-persName ref="#THI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Thiers</tei-persName> : </tei-p>
    <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">Art. 1. The provision of our ordinance of May 25 of this year, which convened the Chamber of Peers and the Chamber of Deputies for August 20, 1834, is revoked.<tei-pb n="29" facs="v1n1p29" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>Art. 2. The Chamber of Peers and the Chamber of Deputies are convened for the next July 31.</tei-p></tei-q>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">The <tei-title data-origname="title"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Moniteur</tei-emph></tei-title> publishes immediately after, but in the non-official section, the following communication which explains the significance of this measure:</tei-p>
    <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">The meeting of the chambers was scheduled for August 20th next. It is now brought forward and set, by this day's ordinance, to July 31st. The king, who in August will be traveling to the southern provinces he has not yet visited, did not want to be absent at the time of the chambers' assembly. Furthermore, this assembly does not have its usual importance: it is convened for the execution of Article 42 of the Charter. However, the government cannot and should not commence their work at that time; no bills, no budget proposals could be ready. Besides, our parliamentary traditions fix the period for the chambers' work between the months of December and May, during the winter season. To begin them in the middle of summer would be an unfortunate departure from established customs. Three hundred deputies from the former chamber, now part of the new one, have already spent five months in Paris this year and could hardly return in July. It is, therefore, appropriate to postpone the work to the customary time. Consequently, after convening the chambers on July 31 and having them in session, the king, using the right of prorogation, will prorogue them until the end of the year to begin the important work of the new legislature at that time.</tei-p></tei-q>
     <tei-p data-origname="p">Proroguing the chambers before they are constituted would be another outrage to add to all those we witness daily. The chambers cannot be prorogued before the new powers of the deputies are verified. If this violation of the Charter were to occur, we will return to this subject.</tei-p></tei-div>
    <tei-div data-origname="div">
     <tei-head data-origname="head">ELECTORAL NEWS.</tei-head>
     <tei-p data-origname="p">We believe it is necessary to inform about the election to the new legislature of deputies who have always taken a particular interest in colonial issues.</tei-p>
     <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#AD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. DELABORDE</tei-persName> was elected both in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Paris</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Étampes (Seine-et<tei-pb n="30" facs="v1n1p30" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>Oise)</tei-placeName>. Undoubtedly, one might wish for a bit more severity from this honorable deputy toward the advisors to the crown. Nevertheless, we will never hesitate to acknowledge Mr. Delaborde's pure intentions, and we are confident that the cause of people of color will always find support and protection in him.</tei-p>
     <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#TRA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. DE TRACY</tei-persName> was elected in two electoral districts in Allier. This choice honors the constituents even more than the representative. Mr. de Tracy is the advocate of all noble causes and, in that capacity, the most genuine and eloquent voice for the oppressed in our colonies.</tei-p>
       <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#FI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. ISAMBERT</tei-persName> was reelected in <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Vendée Luçon</tei-placeName>. We congratulate the voters of Luçon for renewing the mandate of the courageous defender of the deportees from <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, a man as upright as he is enlightened, who never lets an injustice pass without denouncing it and who has never failed the sacred cause of humanity.</tei-p>
       <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#GdL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. GAETAN DE LA ROCHEFOUCAULD</tei-persName> was elected in the department of Cher. We can only applaud this choice, which sends one of the most zealous champions of the abolition of slavery back to the chamber.</tei-p>
       <tei-p data-origname="p">Among the most regrettable losses for people of color in the recent elections, we must first mention <tei-persName ref="#ES" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Eusèbe Salverte</tei-persName>.</tei-p>
       <tei-p data-origname="p">In the <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">5th electoral district of Paris</tei-placeName>, <tei-persName ref="#THI" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Thiers </tei-persName> defeated this honorable citizen. It is the victory of intrigue over patriotic austerity personified in the person of Mr. Salverte. Mr. the Minister of the Interior is the pale reflection of <tei-persName ref="#Talle" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. de Talleyrand</tei-persName>, that archetype and patriarch of political roués, just as Mr. Salverte offers us the pure and living image of the virtuous <tei-persName ref="#CAR" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Carnot</tei-persName>.</tei-p>
       <tei-p data-origname="p">Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#Chara" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Charamaule</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#Meril" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mérilhou</tei-persName> were also not re-elected. Let us hope that the re-elections that will take place due to double nominations will rectify this loss or, rather, this injustice.</tei-p><tei-pb n="31" facs="v1n1p31" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/></tei-div>
       <tei-div data-origname="div">
       <tei-head data-origname="head">MISCELLANEOUS NEWS.</tei-head>
       <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">The following article, published by the <tei-bibl type="periodical" data-origname="bibl" data-origatts="type"><tei-title ref="#MU" data-origname="title" data-origatts="ref">Moniteur</tei-title></tei-bibl> of <tei-date data-origname="date">July 2</tei-date>, is undoubtedly an indirect response to the new information provided about the state of the colony of <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
       <tei-p data-origname="p">In a letter dated May 21st, <tei-persName ref="#EH" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Vice-Admiral Halgan, Governor of Martinique</tei-persName>, reported to the Minister of the Navy on a tour he had just made to several communes of the colony.</tei-p>
       <tei-p data-origname="p">The following passages are noteworthy in this report: </tei-p>
        <tei-floatingText data-origname="floatingText"><tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">I am happy to report that the population is perfectly calm in all the areas I visited, and everyone is focused on taking advantage of a favorable year for the harvest.</tei-p>
        <tei-p data-origname="p">I conducted a thorough examination of the internal management of the plantations and the treatment the slaves receive from their masters. The administration generally seemed to me paternal and wise. Punishments are falling into disuse, and on most of the properties where I stopped, I observed that the masters had affection for their slaves who, without concern for the future, are content with the present, attached to their homes, the small comfort they enjoy, and willingly engage in work that does not exceed their physical capabilities.</tei-p></tei-q></tei-floatingText>
           <tei-p data-origname="p">Thus, Vice-Admiral Halgan's testimony regarding the situation of the slaves in Martinique is very similar to that of <tei-persName ref="#JHD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Rear-Admiral Dupotet</tei-persName>, whom he replaced, and who himself had merely confirmed the reports of his predecessor on this matter. This unanimity of opinions from individuals holding high positions and who were well-placed to know the truth seems to us of a nature to dispel many unjust prejudices and convince that the lot of the slaves in French colonies today leaves little to be desired for friends of humanity.</tei-p>
           <tei-p data-origname="p">Would it not be permissible to point out that this unanimity among the governors might only prove one thing, namely, that they have been, since their arrival,<tei-pb n="32" facs="v1n1p32" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>influenced by the same factors? And as for Mr. Halgan in particular, who has barely arrived on the island, who has seen but a few plantations, and who dismisses the pleas presented to him, he is an authority that can, at this point, be challenged.</tei-p></tei-q>
           <tei-p data-origname="p">(<tei-emph data-origname="emph">Messager</tei-emph>.)</tei-p>
           <tei-p data-origname="p">If one is to believe the official newspaper, wouldn't the slaves be in a real <tei-emph data-origname="emph">el dorado</tei-emph>, enjoying the tranquil and pure happiness that is only found in the shepherds' tales of Durfé and Florian? One must truly lack shame to advance such obviously false claims. Let the <tei-title data-origname="title"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Moniteur</tei-emph></tei-title> then provide us with <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Admiral Halgan</tei-persName>, report without reservations, and let it tell us whether the masters mentioned by the admiral as having murdered slaves are cherished by those who have witnessed the mutilation of their brothers. We call for the <tei-emph data-origname="emph">complete and unaltered report</tei-emph>, but they dare not present it in its entirety, for it would suffice to reveal the extent of the slaves' happiness. In an upcoming issue, we will examine this report and address the <tei-title data-origname="title"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">Moniteur</tei-emph></tei-title>'s deliberate omissions.</tei-p></tei-div>
           <tei-div xml:id="coloniesfr" id="coloniesfr" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
           <tei-head data-origname="head">FRENCH COLONIES.</tei-head>
           <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">CAYENNE.</tei-placeName></tei-head>
           
           <tei-p data-origname="p">We receive the following letter from <tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cayenne</tei-placeName>, containing considerations on the electoral law, the importance of which our readers will understand.</tei-p>
           <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-q data-origname="q">The colonial legislation published in <tei-placeName ref="#GF" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Guiana</tei-placeName>,</tei-q> it says, <tei-q data-origname="q">is the subject of numerous complaints. Men of color have found truel disappointment in the electoral law; hence, those who could meet the 200 francs census have shown great indifference in participating in the elections. In contrast, whites have viewed the consecration of their privileges with a deep sense of satisfaction. Since the bill for the abolition of slavery has passed in England, our aristocrats would be willing to introduce two men of color into the colonial council out of sixteen, provided they are obedient individuals with no connection to <tei-persName ref="#CB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Bissette</tei-persName>, that eternal enemy of colonial interests.</tei-q></tei-p><tei-pb n="33" facs="v1n1p33" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
           <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-emph data-origname="emph">SUPPLEMENT</tei-emph></tei-p>
           <tei-q data-origname="q"><tei-p data-origname="p">Finally, they have reached this result, and two men of color have been admitted in the council, which is nothing but a true mockery, as one knows what influence they can have in deliberations. This de facto exclusion of men of color is a consequence of the exaggerated elevation of the electoral census, which has been designed in such a way as to keep them away.</tei-p>
           <tei-p data-origname="p">To be convinced of this, one need only look at the list of voters, established on October 13, 1833, for <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">French Guiana</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>

<tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">MARTINIQUE.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The magistrates who are to compose the assize court in the Grand'Anse case are: <tei-persName ref="#PER" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Perrinelle</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#RL" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">RICHARD-LUCY</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#LePell" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Le Pelletier-Duclary</tei-persName>. Certainly, to transform innocent individuals into guilty ones, one could not have chosen better than these eternal judges under all regimes.</tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p">Mr. Perrinelle, in the infamous 1824 trial, was one of the three judges out of twelve who voted for the death penalty. RICHARD LUCY, the prosecutor-general at that time, carried out the judgment that sentenced them to perpetual hard labor and branding, in disregard of the appeal to cassation by the condemned. Mr. Le Pelletier-Duclary, a troubled mind, presided, requesting the application of the penalty dictated by his colleague RICHARD-LUCY.</tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p">If one still needs further proof of the morality of this case, suffice it to name the two colonial counselors, Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#JorLa" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">MM. Jorna Lacalle</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#ABour" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Alphonse Bourke</tei-persName>, who rendered the order<tei-pb n="34" facs="v1n1p34" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>for the trial before the assizes. Mr. Jorna Lacalle voted for the death penalty in the 1824 case. This magistrate is utterly incompetent. Mr. Alphonse Bourke never completed his law degree, but in the 1824 trial, he voted for the penalty of perpetual hard labor, and as a conscientious judge, he personally ensured the execution of the judgment to which he had contributed. His victims, bound to the stake, could easily see him from one of the windows of the house of his godmother, Mme Duclésemur, where he was stationed.</tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p">-On May 19th, the drawing of lots was carried out for the four assessors who will sit on the assize court. They are: Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#Baud" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Baudin</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#HuyD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Huygues-Despointes</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#DuDu" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Duval-Dugué</tei-persName> (of Grand'Anse) and <tei-persName ref="#Germa" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Germa</tei-persName>. Mr. Duval-Dagué is a complainant and a key witness in the case he is called to judge. The indictment states, on page 39, that two of the accused looted rum on his plantation. The accused were unable to have him recused because Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#AuA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">Aubert-Armard</tei-orig><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Aubert-Armand</tei-corr></tei-persName>, the public prosecutor, and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Selles</tei-persName>, the royal judge, did not find any incompatibility in a white man judging blacks and mulattos while being a complainant and a witness.<tei-emph data-origname="emph">The respective character of Assessor Duval-Dugué and the accused precludes any idea of recrimination between them...</tei-emph></tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p">-When the accused from Grand'Anse were transferred from the prison to the courthouse for the drawing of lots for the assessors, an extraordinary deployment of troops took place; sentinels placed every ten paces prevented any gathering. Leading were Messrs. <tei-persName ref="#LTelem" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Léonce</tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#ATelem" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Arthur Télémaque</tei-persName>, handcuffed like all their co-accused. An escort of eighty gendarmes was formed, and two companies of riflemen brought up the rear.</tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p">-<tei-persName data-origname="persName"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">M. Armand Aubert</tei-orig><tei-corr data-origname="corr">M. Aubert-Armand</tei-corr></tei-persName>, the public prosecutor in Saint-Pierre, no doubt wanting to show his bias towards men of color, pursues them with a series of petty and miserable harassments, certain signs of a narrow and petty mind. This magistrate pushes the limits of propriety to the point of refusing the titles of <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Mr.</tei-emph> and <tei-emph data-origname="emph">Mrs.</tei-emph> to the relatives of the defendants in the Grand'Anse case who requested from him permission to see the unfortunate prisoners. It seems that the colonial atmosphere has a powerful effect on Europeans predisposed to vanity, as they quickly adopt such ridiculous and silly attitudes.</tei-p><tei-pb n="35" facs="v1n1p35" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">Shortly after the July Revolution, this same magistrate, appointed royal judge in <tei-placeName ref="#Cay" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Cayenne</tei-placeName>, did not hesitate to seek advice from one of the representatives of people of color in <tei-placeName ref="#Par" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Paris</tei-placeName>. He wanted, he said, to enlighten himself in order to enforce the laws despite the ill will of the colonists. At that time, it is true, he often met this representative in the salons of the Minister of Justice, where he was received. This explains many things.</tei-p>
</tei-div>

<tei-div data-origname="div">
<tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#GP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">GUADELOUPE.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

<tei-p data-origname="p">The political situation remains the same; however, there is more tranquility, which probably results less from the satisfaction of the parties than from the weariness they feel from these continuous and fruitless clashes. There has been, therefore, a sort of truce during which young white and colored people have come closer, shaken hands, and mutually promised to live as brothers from now on. May this commitment endure!</tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p">The colonial council has not formulated a single decree; it has, until now, only engaged in opposition to the proposed improvements. Thus, the government, foreseeing that it will be overwhelmed sooner or later by this new institution, is not very pleased with it.</tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p">The consolidation of the National Guard remains a question; the council has not yet made any decisions on this matter.</tei-p></tei-div>

 <tei-div data-origname="div">
 <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#BrB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">BOURBON.</tei-placeName></tei-head>
 <tei-p data-origname="p">The situation in this colony is beginning to feel the effects of some improvements made to the colonial system since the July Revolution. Caste prejudices are decreasing and will eventually disappear as institutions receive further development.</tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p">There is hope that in the upcoming elections, people of color will be appointed to the general council. Already, a large number of votes are assured in favor of <tei-persName ref="#LEl" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Louis Elie</tei-persName>, who enjoys great respect in the country.</tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p">There is some activity in the organization of militias, and, in general, there is no reason to complain about local authorities. As for trade, it is virtually non-existent, and prospects for the future are quite bleak. <tei-pb n="36" facs="v1n1p36" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
 The re-election of <tei-persName ref="#SUB" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Sully-Brunet</tei-persName>, as a delegate, which seemed doubtful, now appears to be assured.</tei-p></tei-div>

 <tei-div data-origname="div">
 <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#Alg" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">ALGER.</tei-placeName></tei-head>
 
 <tei-p data-origname="p">This important possession, whose colonization we hope not to be delayed much longer, is beginning to enjoy some advantages - the inevitable results of its geographical position and the fertile land that extends from the sea to the foothills of the Atlas Mountains. The cessation of hostilities by the indigenous people, renewed confidence, and more active commercial transactions are the first outcomes of a fairer administration; indeed, justice is the primary good for any people, even the barbarians themselves sacrifice at its altars. So what benefits will France gain from this beautiful colony if the government manages it with the broad and philanthropic principles that alone can foster unity between the conquered and the conqueror!</tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#BEO" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Ben-Omar</tei-persName>, the former bey of <tei-placeName data-origname="placeName">Titeri</tei-placeName>, remains our faithful ally, and more powerful than armies, his conciliatory and wise words make us new allies or strengthen the peaceful disposition of those we have acquired.</tei-p>
 <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName ref="#BZ" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Ben-Zegri</tei-persName>, a defector from Constantine, and the Jew Narboni, schemers who played a significant role during previous administrations, are now entirely disgraced and have lost the positions they managed to retain under all regimes. Upon hearing this news, the Atlas Mountains Arabs have shown willingness to draw closer to us, which they did not do previously.</tei-p>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">So, France should hasten to organize this beautiful colony, and above all, not forget this great principle: the art of governing is not the art of oppression.</tei-p></tei-div>

  <tei-div xml:id="coloniesetr" id="coloniesetr" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
  <tei-head data-origname="head">FOREIGN COLONIES.</tei-head>
  <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#StT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">SAINT-THOMAS.</tei-placeName></tei-head>
  
  <tei-p data-origname="p">If the colonial aristocracy contented itself with persecuting the men of color they deem dangerous, they would only partly fulfill their mission; they must also pursue, even in foreign lands, the unfortunate individuals who have incurred their animosity. Aristocratic <tei-pb n="37" facs="v1n1p37" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>hatreds are as tenacious as those of kings, and just as <tei-persName ref="#NIC" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Nicnolas</tei-persName> pursues the remnants of Poland worldwide, or <tei-persName ref="#C-A" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Charles-Albert</tei-persName> claims his victims everywhere, colonial aristocracy also roars with fury when an unfortunate soul condemned to the executioner manages to escape it. Their minions track down such individuals everywhere, and if treaties, which they can render as flexible as laws, provide a means, extradition satisfies their thirst for mulatto blood and their obsession with punishment.</tei-p>
  <tei-p data-origname="p">After the events of the Grand'Anse, a man of color, <tei-persName ref="#AHav" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Mr. Auguste Havre</tei-persName>, took refuge on the Danish island of <tei-placeName ref="#StT" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Thomas</tei-placeName>, espérant y trouver un asile où ses persécuteurs ne viendraient pas le troubler. Son erreur était grande ! <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Morin</tei-persName>, the son of a pharmacist from <tei-placeName ref="#StP" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Pierre</tei-placeName>, went to Saint Thomas, recognized him, and this young colonist reported him as a supporter of the Grand'Anse revolution to <tei-persName ref="#MACK" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Admiral Mackau</tei-persName>, Admiral Mackau, the commander of the Antilles station, who happened to be in that Danish colony at the time. This admiral who, for good reasons, shares colonial prejudices, requested the extradition of Mr. Auguste Havre in order to hand him over to the authorities in Martinique. He may well obtain it from the Danish government which, despite its usual gentleness, may be influenced by the fear of displeasing the French Ministry of the Navy.</tei-p>
   <tei-p data-origname="p">However, one must hope that the Saint Thomas government will be dignified enough not to sacrifice the peace and lives of the unfortunate individuals who come to its shores to the demands of a faction. Where would we be if the sacred laws of hospitality could be violated with impunity?</tei-p></tei-div>

   <tei-div data-origname="div">
   <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#STL" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">SAINTE-LUCIA.</tei-placeName></tei-head>

   <tei-p data-origname="p">Before his departure from <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, former Governor <tei-persName ref="#JHD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Dupotet</tei-persName> solicited the extradition of several of the accused in the Grand'Anse conspiracy who had taken refuge on the island of <tei-placeName ref="#STL" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Sainte-Lucie</tei-placeName> offering to exchange these unfortunate individuals for several escaped slaves from Saint Lucia. The English governor responded with dignity, stating that he did not accept the proposition and that he could not do so without the consent of his government. He believed too highly in the British ministry to entertain the notion that they would support such a dishonest action. Shortly <tei-pb n="38" facs="v1n1p38" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>after, when this governor had passed away, Mr. Dupotet did not hesitate to repeat his request with his successor. Such measures can only be conceived by minds accustomed to sycophantic servility, which, likening humans to properties, believe that governments can trade, sell, or barter them at their whim. However, nothing here should be surprising; it is known that Admiral Dupotet, like all the minor colonial despots in charge of exploiting the colonies, is united in heart, affection, and interest with the privileged class in these regions.</tei-p></tei-div>

    <tei-div data-origname="div">
    <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-placeName ref="#DOM" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">DOMINIQUE.</tei-placeName></tei-head>
    
    <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-placeName ref="#DOM" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Dominica</tei-placeName>, formerly a French colony but now part of <tei-placeName ref="#GB" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Great Britain</tei-placeName> is, of all the Caribbean islands, the one where color prejudices have the least hold. One could even say that they no longer exist since people of color hold public office just like whites, without any rivalry between them except that of merit. It's not surprising, therefore, that this hospitable island, which is also adjacent to <tei-placeName ref="#MQ" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Martinique</tei-placeName>, Martinique, is a refuge for our unfortunate compatriots who are persecuted. Well, General <tei-persName ref="#JHD" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Dupotet</tei-persName>, former governor of Martinique, has also made an offer to the governor of this colony for a deal in human flesh. Like his counterpart in <tei-placeName ref="#STL" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">Saint-Lucia</tei-placeName>, the latter has categorically refused. Honorable people can be found everywhere.</tei-p></tei-div>

    <tei-div xml:id="necrologie" id="necrologie" data-origname="div" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-head data-origname="head">NECROLOGY.</tei-head>
    <tei-head data-origname="head"><tei-persName ref="#LaF" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">THE GENERAL LAFAYETTE</tei-persName></tei-head>
    
    <tei-p data-origname="p">Among the defenders of humanity, the most steadfast, unquestionably the most virtuous, and the most dedicated was <tei-persName ref="#LaF" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Lafayette</tei-persName>Lafayette. He is no more! He passed away on May 20th from an illness he contracted while attending the funeral procession of the unfortunate Dulong. Despite experiencing some signs of illness himself, the old general insisted on being present and followed him devoutly, on foot, from the mortuary house to the grave prepared to receive the mortal remains of <tei-pb n="39" facs="v1n1p39" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>our dear friend. The death of Dulong hastened Lafayette's own demise. For those of us who loved the young deputy and had the privilege of closely observing the admirable old age of the illustrious friend of <tei-persName ref="#WAS" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Washington</tei-persName>, this was a double source of sorrow.</tei-p>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">The name of Lafayette will live as long as the selflessness of personal interests and pure, unwavering devotion to the cause of all are honored among men. Born into one of the oldest families in France and recently married to Madame de Noailles, a sudden transformation occurred in the excellent nature of this young French nobleman that permanently converted him to the democratic cause. It was like a revelation from above that determined the course of his life. He was but seeking a field where he could worthily employ his noble faculties when news of the American insurrection arrived in Europe. The young husband of Madame de Noailles, the dashing cavalier whose grace and elegant manners were praised at Versailles, had hardly read the American Declaration of Independence before he was won over. Reading the Bill of Rights turned Mr. de Lafayette into what we have seen him become: an indefatigable advocate for the oppressed, without regard to nationality or color, and the most sincere and ardent proponent of universal freedom.</tei-p>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">The intrepid volunteer arrived with incredible joy on the soil where he was about to shed his blood, where <tei-persName ref="#JEF" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Jefferson</tei-persName>, <tei-persName ref="#ADA" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">Adam</tei-orig><tei-corr data-origname="corr">Adams</tei-corr></tei-persName> and <tei-persName ref="#WAS" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="ref">Washington</tei-persName> awaited him, and he only returned after ensuring, along with his illustrious friends, through the surrender at Yorktown that ended the War of Independence in October 1781, the national existence of the great and serene republic that was always the object of his strong and patriotic affection.</tei-p>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">The political life of Mr. Lafayette is well-known: the generous role he played in the 1789 revolution, the strength of his logic, the simple clarity, and the unwavering faith with which he advocated, in the <tei-orgName ref="#AN" data-origname="orgName" data-origatts="ref">National Assembly</tei-orgName> and the <tei-orgName ref="#AC" data-origname="orgName" data-origatts="ref">Constituent Assembly</tei-orgName>, the sacred principles for which we fight, do not need to be reiterated. More than once, he raised his voice against the enslavement of black people and the injustice that excluded people of color from the exercise of their civic rights, but unfortunately, often without success.</tei-p>
    <tei-p data-origname="p">In this regard, he did not limit himself to theory; he also added practice, a rarer thing: starting in 1791, the General emancipated all the <tei-pb n="40" facs="v1n1p40" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>slaves in his possessions in <tei-placeName ref="#GF" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="ref">French Guiana</tei-placeName>. And on this account, he should be particularly dear to black people and people of color, for whom he never ceased to demand freedom and all the privileges of white citizens.</tei-p>
     <tei-p data-origname="p">In that same year, <tei-date data-origname="date">1791</tei-date>, he spoke these memorable words from the podium: <tei-q data-origname="q">According to the decrees of the National Assembly, I believe it is clear that free <tei-emph data-origname="emph">men</tei-emph>, property owners, cultivators, and taxpayers are <tei-emph data-origname="emph">citizens</tei-emph>. Now, men of color are property owners, cultivators, taxpayers; are they <tei-emph data-origname="emph">men</tei-emph>? </tei-q>(Barely restrained applause. He continued with the subtle irony that was familiar to him): <tei-q data-origname="q">For my part, I believe they are; and it is to express my opinion that I have requested the floor.</tei-q>At this point, the audience could no longer contain themselves, and applause and cheers drowned out the speaker's voice.</tei-p>
       <tei-p data-origname="p">In the committee that was tasked, after the July Revolution, with examining a bill on the same issue, and which only produced the imperfect law that governs us, he displayed the greatest zeal for the extension of political rights for men of color. However, the stubbornness and narrow prejudices of his colleagues paralyzed his goodwill.</tei-p>
       <tei-p data-origname="p">Throughout his long career, concerning general politics, Mr. Lafayette made mistakes on occasion; in particular, he allowed himself to be deceived. We regret that he let slip, for the good of mankind, the few beautiful opportunities that presented themselves to him to settle everything according to his principles in the affairs of France and consequently in those of the entire world. But, despite all, it must be acknowledged that no man has, with a more noble character, followed a more honorable and upright course of conduct, even in the face of some apparent contradictions. Perhaps Lafayette alone, among historical figures, has managed to give practical and positive reality to what is meant by the sacred word <tei-q data-origname="q">virtue</tei-q>.</tei-p>

  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n13FA" id="n13FA" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">La <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies </tei-title>souscrit pleinement à la mode, importée d’Angleterre dans les années 1800, des périodiques non-quotidiens destinés essentiellement à une élite lettrée. Comme l’indique la désignation « recueil » dans le sous-titre, il s’agit d’une compilation de textes divers sélectionnés par le directeur comme représentatifs de l’actualité politique, administrative, juridique, et culturelle du monde colonial. La forme éditoriale de la revue (de son étymologie anglaise, <tei-title data-origname="title">review</tei-title>, c’est-à-dire, bilan ou récapitulatif) vise en effet, autant par sa structure que par sa périodicité, à faire la synthèse des événements marquants des semaines écoulées. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">La <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>s’attache également à sensibiliser le lecteur métropolitain aux conditions de vie des populations de couleur, libres ou esclavisées, des territoires coloniaux ainsi qu’à promouvoir l’apport culturel, littéraire et artistique d’auteurs et personnalités de couleur avec des rubriques spécialisées, d’où l’insistence du sous-titre sur les « moeurs » et l’« instruction ».</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Comme toutes les publications de son genre, la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>répond plus du livre que du journal par son format (grand in-octavo), sa mise en page traditionnelle et la taille, relativement conséquente, de ses livraisons (de 40 à 48 pages). Celles-ci sont d’ailleurs destinées à être reliées en fin d’année afin d’être recueillies, comme des livres, dans les bibliothèques, ainsi qu’en atteste la numérotation continue des pages, introduite dès le second volume. Régulier au cours des deux premières années, le tirage de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>sera sujet, par la suite, à des interruptions ponctuelles jusqu’à l’arrêt définitif de sa publication en juin 1842. </tei-p>

    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">The form of the “review,” a non-daily periodical offering a survey of current events, commentary, and reprinted material, originates in Romantic-era English print culture.  As indicated by the designation “compendium” in the subtitle, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title> is a compilation of various texts selected by the editors as representative of the political, administrative, legal and cultural news of the colonial world. In choosing the form of the “review” (in the sense of survey or evaluation), the journal indicates its aim to summarize the significant occurrences of the previous weeks.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Like most publications of its kind, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, printed in-octavo, with single column pages, in relatively long issues (40 to 50 pages), more closely resembles a book than a newspaper. Issues are designed to be bound at the end of each year in order to be collected as volumes, as evidenced by the continuous numbering of the pages between issues, beginning in the second year of the journal's print run. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Though making the metropolitan French reader aware of the hardships experienced by people of color, free or enslaved, was the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title>'s main objective, it also aimed to promote the literary, artistic, and cultural contributions of contemporaneous writers and historical figures of color. It did so through regular features and reprints, hence the insistence, in the subtitle, on “customs” and “instruction.”</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Printed regularly over the first two years, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> was, thereafter, subject to occasional interruptions until its final issue in June 1842.</tei-p>

  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n4F2A" id="n4F2A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">

      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette notion de « fusion » revient souvent dans la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, qui lui consacre, notamment, un article intitulé « De la fusion des deux races aux colonies et des causes qui la retardent » (décembre 1834, p. 1-7). Proposée comme moyen d’abolir la hiérarchie raciale des colonies par le métissage, elle peut paraître utopique, voire naïve. Comme l’a signalé Marlene Daut, elle demeure néanmoins ancrée, pour Bissette et ses associés, dans une conscience nécessaire des rapports de force profondément inégalitaires que le métissage impliquait, en pratique, dans le contexte colonial. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Bongie, Chris. <tei-title data-origname="title">Islands and Exiles: The Creole Identities of Post/colonial Literature</tei-title>, Stanford, Californie : Stanford University Press, 1998, p. 274-275.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Daut, Marlene L. <tei-title data-origname="title">Tropics of Haiti</tei-title>, Liverpool : Liverpool University Press, 2015, p. 345‑372.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Manchuelle, François. « Le rôle des Antillais dans l’apparition du nationalisme culturel en Afrique noire francophone », <tei-title data-origname="title">Cahiers d'Études Africaines</tei-title> 32, no. 127, 1992, p. 375‑408.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This notion of “fusion” appears frequently in the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, notably in article in the December 1834 issue entitled “Of the fusion of the two races in the colonies and the causes that delay it” (“De la fusion des deux races aux colonies et des causes qui la retardent,” <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue des Colonies</tei-title>, December 1834, 1-7). As Marlene Daut has noted, for the "society of men of color" at the helm of the journal, this notion of fusion remains inextricable from the history of sexual violence that racial mixing implied, in practice, in the colonial context.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Bongie, Chris. <tei-title data-origname="title">Islands and Exiles: The Creole Identities of Post/colonial Literature</tei-title>. Stanford: Stanford University Press, 1998, 274-275.</tei-p>

  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n6CEA" id="n6CEA" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette phrase apporte un éclairage essentiel sur la politique éditoriale de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>à ses débuts. Si l’objectif est de combattre le système esclavagiste en commençant, en premier lieu, par le démantèlement de l’ordre ségregationniste des colonies par la revendication des droits civiques des personnes de couleur libres, la voie choisie par Bissette et ses associés dans cette première livraison est, que ce soit pour des raisons idéologiques sincères ou pour des raisons stratégiques, celle de la conciliation et de l’assimilationnisme social. Il n’y est, par ailleurs, pas question d’envisager une quelconque indépendance des Antilles, et ce particulièrement dans une décennie qui voit la France étendre son empire à l’Algérie après avoir perdu plusieurs territoires de son premier empire colonial. La perspective que Bissette affiche par le biais de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> reste celle d’un Français qui croit à la vitalité de l’Empire et n’envisage pas d’alternative au système colonial. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This claim is indicative of the editorial politics of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> in its early days. Though the ultimate goal remains the abolition of slavery and the dismantlement of the colonies' segregationist order, Bissette and his associates adopt an overhwelmingly assimilationist and conciliatory position with regard to metropolitan France. This may be a pragmatic decision, given the slim possibility of independence for the Caribbean colonies, in the decade that saw France extend its empire to Algeria. The position Bissette adopts throughout the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>’s print run is, thus, ostensibly that of a colonial and imperial subject who does not see the need to pursue any alternative forms of governance.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n79DB" id="n79DB" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Si Bissette et ses associés Fabien et Richard avaient rédigé, au cours des deux années précédentes, plusieurs textes et pétitions à visée explicitement émancipatrice, cette déclaration suggère une approche plus conciliante, sans doute par souci d’attirer un nombre important d’abonnés, mais aussi, potentiellement, par crainte de censure officielle ou de répercussions juridiques. Un an plus tard, la première livraison du second volume tient un discours bien plus explicitement et résolument abolitionniste. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-ref target="RdCv2n1-fr" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Juillet 1835</tei-ref></tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Unlike the more explicitly emancipatory tracts that Bissette and his associates Fabien and Richard had drafted over the previous two years, this declaration suggests a more conciliatory approach, likely out of concern for attracting and maintaining subscribers, but also, potentially, for fear of official censorship or legal repercussions. A year later, the first issue of the second volume features markedly more radical abolitionist arguments.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-ref target="RdCv2n1-en" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">July 1835</tei-ref></tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n6ED7" id="n6ED7" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cet oxymore souligne l’attitude paradoxale de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> et de son rédacteur quant au projet colonial. Comme beaucoup de ses contemporains, le libéralisme de Bissette, même lorsqu’il est au plus explicite dans ses engagements antiesclavagistes et antiségrégationnistes, n’est jamais explicitement décolonial. Toutefois, l’apparente adhésion, voire la « dévotion » de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> au modèle colonial, mérite d’être nuancée, notamment par les propos tenus dès l’année suivante, dans <tei-ref target="RdCv2n1-fr#abolition" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">l’article sur le projet de loi pour l’abolition immédiate</tei-ref>. La France y est invoquée, de manière ouvertement pragmatique, au titre d’arbitre nécessaire à la transition de « l’ancien au nouvel état produit par l’abolition de l’esclavage », dans une allusion claire à l’embargo économique et diplomatique d’Haïti aux lendemains de son idépendance. (juillet 1835, p. 10)</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This oxymoron underlines the paradoxical attitude  the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> adopts regarding France's imperial and colonial project. Bissette's liberalism does not explicitly extend from anti-slavery to anti-colonialism. However, the apparent adhesion, even “devotion,” of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> to the French empire, is not without complication, particularly in its discussion of the <tei-ref target="RdCv2n1-en#abolition" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">bill for immediate abolition published the following year</tei-ref>. France is invoked there, in the spirit of pragmatism, as the necessary arbiter for the transition from “the old to the new state produced by the abolition of slavery,” in a clear allusion to the economic and diplomatic embargo of Haiti in the aftermath of its independence. (July 1835, 10)</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n65C6" id="n65C6" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Une série d’articles intitulés « Affaire de la Grand’Anse » paraît dans les trois premières livraisons de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, revenant sur les particularités de l’affaire et la procédure judiciaire qui s'en est suivie tout au long de la première année.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">A series of articles entitled “Affaire de la Grand’Anse” appeared in the first three issues of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, detailing the specifics of the case and the legal proceedings that followed.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n2BFD" id="n2BFD" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette expression vise à mettre en équivalence le statut privilégié des colons blancs avec celui qui est réservé à la noblesse, et par extension à opérer un parallèle entre la hiérarchie raciale de la société coloniale et celle de l’Ancien Régime. De fait, l’ensemble des diverses mesures discriminatoires mises en place par les ordonnances coloniales à l’encontre de la population de couleur libre est souvent désigné par l’expression « préjugé de couleur », ce qui en fait le pendant colonial du préjugé de noblesse de la France d’Ancien Régime. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Régent, Frédéric. « Préjugé de couleur, esclavage et citoyennetés dans les colonies françaises (1789-1848) », <tei-title data-origname="title">La Révolution française</tei-title>. 17 novembre 2015 n<tei-hi rend="superscript" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">o</tei-hi> 9.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This original expression analogizes the privileged status of white settlers in the colonies to that of Old Regime nobility. In so doing, it echoes the phrase “prejudice of color,” which was used to refer collectively to the various discriminatory measures put in place by colonial ordinances against the free population of color.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Régent, Frédéric. “Préjugé de couleur, esclavage et citoyennetés dans les colonies françaises (1789-1848),”  <tei-title data-origname="title">La Révolution française</tei-title> 9 (2015). 1-37.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n7A20" id="n7A20" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Référence transparente aux victimes de l’<tei-title data-origname="title">affaire Bissette</tei-title>, dont Bissette et Fabien, mais également à celles de l’<tei-title data-origname="title">affaire de la Grand’Anse.</tei-title></tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This is a transparent allusion to the victims of the <tei-title data-origname="title">affaire Bissette</tei-title>, including the founders of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, as well as those of the <tei-title data-origname="title">affaire de la Grand’Anse</tei-title>.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n4C92" id="n4C92" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="commentaire" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Déclaration aussi surprenante qu’évocatrice des engagements réels de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue.</tei-title></tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="commentary" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This passage of elevated rhetoric effectively constitutes a mission statement for the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue.</tei-title></tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n5699" id="n5699" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette référence claire à l’abolition de l’esclavage britannique décrétée en août 1833, et devant entrer en vigueur en août 1834, soit quelques semaines après la première livraison de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, permet d’identifier l’'un des moteurs politiques de la fondation du périodique.  La référence comprend également une allusion implicite aux insurrections antiesclavagistes de l’ancienne colonie française de Saint-Domingue qui ont précipité la première abolition française de l’esclavage en 1794. À l’époque de la première livraison de la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, l’émancipation et l’éventuelle indépendance d’Haïti constituent une menace pour les sociétés coloniales et esclavagistes, et exercent de ce fait une influence importante sur l’administration des territoires coloniaux. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This reference to the British Abolition Act, passed in August 1833, which would take effect only a few weeks after the first issue of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>, in August 1834, is indicative of its impetus and political ambitions. The phrasing also appears to make implicit reference to the slave insurrections in the former colony of Saint-Domingue that ultimately brought about the first French abolition in 1794. At the time of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>’s publication, the emancipation and ultimate independence of Haiti were perceived as persistent threats to the colonial system, with lasting effects on French international and colonial policy.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n7767" id="n7767" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Bissette choisit de réimprimer les procès-verbaux, un tirage séparé plus rare, et moins référencé de la Déclaration, qui contenait également les articles de la première Constitution française. Ce document était initialement destiné au cercle restreint de ceux qui ont participé à sa création, avec des copies limitées à ces personnes. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Bissette chooses to reprint the minutes (“procès-verbaux”) of the meetings of the National Constituent Assembly during which the Declaration was discussed and adopted. This rarer, less referenced separate edition of the Declaration, also contained the articles of the first French Constitution. Copies of this document were originally limited to those who participated in its creation.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n590A" id="n590A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Cette <tei-title data-origname="title">affaire</tei-title>, qui a bénéficié d’une couverture médiatique importante dans la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> et ailleurs, a pour origine une altercation, en août 1833, entre un planteur blanc et un homme de couleur libre qui aboutit à  une mobilisation fermement réprimée. Sur plus d’une centaine d’accusés, la majorité reçoit de sévères condamnations —  travaux forcés, déportations, exécutions — à l’issue d’un procès expéditif mené par la justice locale. L’article « Coup d’œil sur le régime colonial et ses effets » est d’ailleurs suivi d’un article entièrement consacré à l’« Insurrection de la Grand’Anse » énumérant les 117 accusés.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Schloss, Rebecca Hartkopf. <tei-title data-origname="title">Sweet Liberty : The Final Days of Slavery in Martinique</tei-title> Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2011. p. 152-165.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This <tei-title data-origname="title">affaire</tei-title>, which received significant media coverage in the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> and elsewhere, originated in an altercation in August 1833 between a white planter and a free man of color, ultimately resulting in an authoritarian mass mobilization against protesting men of color. A majority of the more than one hundred arrested received severe sentences — forced labor, deportations, executions — after a hasty trial conducted by local courts. In this issue, the article “A look at the colonial regime and its effects” is followed by an article entirely devoted to the "Grand'Anse Uprising,” which includes a list of the 117 accused.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Schloss, Rebecca Hartkopf. <tei-title data-origname="title">Sweet Liberty: The Final Days of Slavery in Martinique</tei-title> Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2011. 152-165.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n9F29" id="n9F29" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Trois jours d’insurrection parisienne en juillet 1830, les Trois Glorieuses, mettent fin au règne de Charles X et à la Restauration, régime supplanté par la Monarchie de Juillet avec à sa tête, Louis-Philippe, roi des Français.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Three days of insurrection across Paris in July 1830, the so-called <tei-title data-origname="title">Trois Glorieuses</tei-title>, put an end to the reign of Charles X and the Bourbon Restoration, installing, in its place, the July Monarchy of Louis-Philippe, who accepted the title “King of the French.”</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n3257" id="n3257" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">En proclamant, en son article 73, que les colonies seraient régies par « des lois et des règlements particuliers », la Charte constitutionnelle de 1814 cautionnait, de fait, d’importants abus à l’encontre de la population de couleur. L’élimination du mot « règlements » de l’article 64 (par ailleurs identique) de la nouvelle Charte de 1830 signalerait donc, comme l’explique la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue,</tei-title> une volonté de la part du nouveau gouvernement de remédier à la situation en rapprochant les colonies de la métropole. </tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Larcher, Silyane. <tei-title data-origname="title">L’autre citoyen: L’idéal républicain et les Antilles après l’esclavage</tei-title>, Paris. Armand Colin, 2014, p. 114-117.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Per Article 73 of the Constitutional Charter of 1814: “The colonies are governed by specific laws and regulations.” Article 64 of the revised Charter of 1830 is equivalent save for the removal of the word “regulations.” As the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title> explains, the capacity of colonial governments to abide by their own particular “regulations” enabled significant forms of abuse and oppression of people of color. Thus the new charter would appear to reform these injustices by bringing the colonies more in line with the <tei-title data-origname="title">métropole</tei-title>.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Larcher, Silyane. <tei-title data-origname="title">L’autre citoyen: L’idéal républicain et les Antilles après l’esclavage</tei-title>, Paris. Armand Colin, 2014, 114-117.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n917D" id="n917D" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Les titres de noblesse, abolis au début de la Révolution, sont rétablis avec la Restauration de la monarchie en 1814 et maintenus pendant la monarchie de Juillet. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Titles of nobility were abolished at the start of the Revolution but reestablished with the Restoration of the Monarchy in 1814 and maintained during the July Monarchy. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n332A" id="n332A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Les ordonnances locales qui régissent, de fait, les territoires coloniaux, tendent systématiquement à protéger les intérêts des planteurs blancs. Dès 1831, Mondésir Richard objecte auprès du gouvernement métropolitain : « La Charte nous promet des lois, et vous nous replacez inhumainement sous l’empire des ordonnances, et le mauvais vouloir des Colons. »</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Richard, Mondésir. <tei-title data-origname="title">Examen des deux projets de loi sur l'organisation des colonies : et sur les droits civils et politiques des hommes de couleur, </tei-title>Paris, Imprimerie Porthmann, 1831, p. 11.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Local ordinances which <tei-title data-origname="title">de facto</tei-title> govern colonial territories systematically tend to protect the interests of white planters. As early as 1831, Mondésir Richard decried the unjustness of this system to the French government: “The Charter promises us laws, and you inhumanly put us back under the empire of ordinances, and the ill will of the colonists.”</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Richard, Mondésir. <tei-title data-origname="title">Examen des deux projets de loi sur l'organisation des colonies: et sur les droits civils et politiques des hommes de couleur. </tei-title>Paris: Imprimerie Porthmann, 1831. 11.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n0490" id="n0490" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Les lois d’avril 1833, parfois connues sous le nom de <tei-title data-origname="title">Charte coloniale</tei-title>, devaient en principe confirmer l’égalité des populations libres des colonies. Elles ne font cependqnt qu’appuyer l’hégémonie des colons blancs en leur assurant la domination au sein d’assemblées locales et en maintenant des conditions de cens qui leur sont largement favorables.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">The laws passed in April 1833, referred to collectively as the <tei-title data-origname="title">Colonial Charter</tei-title>, were meant, in principle, to confirm the equality of the free populations of the colonies. In practice, however, they ensured white landowners’ control of local assemblies and set tax requirements for voting that barred all but a few men of color from the electoral process.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n8508" id="n8508" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">L’implication ici est que le statut des hommes libres de couleur par rapport aux propriétaires terriens blancs en 1834 est plus dégradé que le statut des gens ordinaires (membres du tiers état, l'ordre le plus bas de la hiérarchie sociale) par rapport au clergé ou à l'aristocratie au cours de la ancien régime, qui étaient au moins reconnus comme ayant des droits égaux à l'humanité.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">The implication here is that the status of free men of color relative to white landowners in 1834 is more degraded than the status of commoners (members of the third estate, the lowest order of the social hierarchy) relative to the clergy or aristocracy during the ancien regime, who were at least recognized as having equal claims to humanity. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n6759" id="n6759" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Un exemple de ce type de concession est l’ordonnance royale du 24 février 1831 permettant aux  « libres de couleur  » de Martinique d’hériter des blancs, d’exercer la médecine, la chirurgie ou la pharmacie, de s’établir en métropole, et d’accèder à l'éducation.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Schloss, Rebecca Hartkopf. <tei-title data-origname="title">Sweet Liberty: The Final Days of Slavery in Martinique</tei-title>. <tei-title data-origname="title">Philadelphia.</tei-title> University of Pennsylvania Press. 2011, p. 136.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">An example of this type of concession is the royal ordinance of February 24, 1831 allowing the free men of color of Martinique to inherit property from whites, to practice medicine, surgery or pharmacy, to settle in metropolitan France, and to receive education.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Schloss, Rebecca Hartkopf. <tei-title data-origname="title">Sweet Liberty: The Final Days of Slavery in Martinique. </tei-title>Philadelphia. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. 2011. 136.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n684A" id="n684A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="contexte_historique" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Ce passage est révélateur du public visé par la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>et de l’objectif qu’elle se donne auprès de celui-ci. Le sensationnalisme qui a pu caractériser le traitement médiatique de l’<tei-title data-origname="title">affairede la Grand’Anse </tei-title>a sans doute éffarouché quelques lecteurs potentiellement favorables à la cause des personnes de couleur, la <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>promet de remédier à cet état de fait en apportant un contrepoids nécessaire, en vue d’éclairer des lecteurs métropolitains bienveillants mais trop éloignés des réalités coloniales.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="historical_context" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This meta-commentary on the state of colonial reporting is revelatory of the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue</tei-title>’s intended audience. If sensationalist coverage of the <tei-title data-origname="title">affaire de la Grand’Anse </tei-title>might have instilled doubts in readers potentially sympathetic to the cause of expanded rights for free people of color, the <tei-title data-origname="title">Revue </tei-title>promises to provide a necessary counterbalance, and thus to attract benevolent but otherwise disengaged metropolitan French readers to the emancipatory cause. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n9C9A" id="n9C9A" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="référence_culturelle" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Il s’agit d’une référence à <tei-title data-origname="title">Turcaret</tei-title>,une comédie populaire de 1709 par Alain-René Lesage, dont le personnage titulaire est un usurier et ancien laquais qui tente de s’insinuer dans l’aristocratie.</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Dans le contexte de la comparaison aux anciens titres de noblesse, l’« aristocratie des Turcarets »</tei-p>
      <tei-p data-origname="p">semble donc faire allusion au système de pairie introduit à la Restauration et calqué sur le système anglais, créant une catégorie de noblesse non héréditaire et transactionnelle.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="cultural_reference" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">This is a reference to <tei-title data-origname="title">Turcaret</tei-title>, a popular comedy from 1709 by Alain-René Lesage, whose titular character is a usurer and former valet who attempts to insinuate himself into the aristocracy. The reference thus appears to be to the recently redefined system of peerage, modeled on the English system, which created a non-hereditary and thus acquirable and transactional category of nobility. </tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n5DA0" id="n5DA0" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
    <tei-note xml:lang="fr" lang="fr" type="référence_culturelle" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Mésence, le tyran étrusque dans l'<tei-title data-origname="title">Énéide</tei-title> de Virgile, Caligula, l’empereur romain connu pour sa cruauté et sa débauche, et Louis XI, emblème du despotisme médiéval dans la littérature romantique, sont ici évoqués pour sous-entendre que la cruauté et la corruption des planteurs et administrateurs coloniaux surpassent celle des personnages historiques ou mythologiques les plus infâmes.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
    <tei-note xml:lang="en" lang="en" type="cultural_reference" data-origname="note" data-origatts="type xml:lang">
      <tei-p data-origname="p">Mésence, or Mezentius, the tyrant Etruscan king in Virgil’s <tei-title data-origname="title">Aeneid</tei-title>, Caligula, the Roman emperor notorious for cruelty and debauchery, and Louis XI, an emblem of dark-age despotism familiar to readers of nineteenth-century French literature, are here evoked with the implication that the cruelty and corruption of white colonial landowners and authorities surpasses that of the most infamous historical, or mythological figures.</tei-p>
    </tei-note>
  </tei-noteGrp>
  <tei-noteGrp xml:id="n3E34" id="n3E34" data-origname="noteGrp" data-origatts="xml:id">
